metadata.template_skill: Student selects best explanation from choices about why a comparison is true

telemetry_data.mastery_skill: Student can select explanation that correctly describes why one fraction is greater

steps.dialogue: Look at this comparison. Why is seven-tenths greater than three-tenths?

options: The fraction with more total pieces is greater.
The denominator is the same, so if 7 > 3, then 7/10 > 3/10.
The bigger the denominator, the bigger the fraction.
The bottom number tells us which fraction is greater.

step.dialogue: Not quite. Look at the denominators in both fractions.

Let's think about this more carefully. Both fractions have the same denominator - they're both tenths. When the denominators are the same, we can compare the numerators directly. What does that tell us about 7/10 and 3/10?

Let me walk you through this reasoning. When we compare fractions, we need to look at what they have in common. Both 7/10 and 3/10 have the same denominator - 10. That means both fractions are made of the same size pieces, tenths. When the pieces are the same size, we just compare how many pieces we have. Since 7 is greater than 3, that means 7 tenths is greater than 3 tenths. So 7/10 > 3/10. That's how we compare fractions with the same denominator - we compare the numerators.

on_correct.dialogue: That's right. That explanation is correct.
